data.title: Movies and TV Shows
data.meta_description: STANLEY LIVINGSTON - Movies and TV Shows
data.text:
The Bonnie Parker Story is a crime film directed by William Witney. It is loosely based on the life of Bonnie Parker, a well-known outlaw of the 1930s. The film stars Dorothy Provine as Parker; Parker's actual historical partner, Clyde Barrow, is renamed Guy Darrow for the film's story, and played by Jack Hogan. The film was released by American International Pictures as a double feature with Machine Gun Kelly starring Charles Bronson. Stan appears as a mischievious little boy who steals the car keys out of Bonnie and Clyde's get-away car and holds them for ransom.

Rally Round the Flag, Boys! is a film adaptation of the novel of the same name by Max Shulman, directed by Leo McCarey, starring Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward, and released by 20th Century Fox. The title comes from a line in the song "Battle Cry of Freedom". Stan play's Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward's oldest son Peter Bannerman. Peter is more interested in watching TV than playing with his Dad.

A Half-Hour Long Television Pilot for a proposed Television Series starring Stanley Livingston. The Pilot was Produced and Directed by Jackie Cooper in December of 1958. Former Little Rascal and Academy Award Nominated Child Star turned Producer-Director wrote this 1958 TV Pilot for Stan to Star in. Jackie also Produced and Directed the half-hour Sitcom.

Please Don't Eat the Daisies is a Metrocolor comedy film in CinemaScope starring Doris Day and David Niven, made by Euterpe Inc., and distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. The movie was directed by Charles Walters and produced by Joe Pasternak, with Martin Melcher as associate producer. Based on the best-selling book and movie of the same name (Please Don't Eat the Daisies. Set in Ridgemont, New York, the Nashes are an unusual suburban family. Jim Nash, a college English professor, and his wife Joan, a newspaper columnist, live with their four rambunctious children and a large shaggy dog named Hobo. Stan plays Doris Day and David Niven's son, Gabrial McKay in this delightful and romantic light comedy.

X-15 is a American aviation drama film that presents a fictionalized account of the X-15 research rocket aircraft program, the test pilots who flew the aircraft, and the associated NASA community. During the Cold War in the 1960s the U.S.A.F.and NASA tested the experimental rocket-powered aircraft X-15 that set altitude and speed records and reached the edge of outer space.. Stan plays Charles Bronson's son in this dawn of the space age thriller. X-15 was the first Feature Film by A-List director, Richard Donner..

How the West Was Won is an American epic Western film directed by Henry Hathaway, John Ford and George Marshall, produced by Bernard Smith, written by James R. Webb, and narrated by Spencer Tracy. Originally filmed in true three-lens Cinerama with the according three-panel panorama projected onto an enormous curved screen, the film stars an ensemble cast consisting of (in alphabetical order) Carroll Baker, Lee J. Cobb, Henry Fonda, Carolyn Jones, Karl Malden, Gregory Peck, George Peppard, Robert Preston, Debbie Reynolds, James Stewart, Eli Wallach, John Wayne and Richard Widmark. The supporting cast features Brigid Bazlen, Walter Brennan, David Brian, Ken Curtis, Andy Devine, Jack Lambert, Raymond Massey as Abraham Lincoln, Agnes Moorehead, Harry Morgan as Ulysses S. Grant, Thelma Ritter, Mickey Shaughnessy, Harry Dean Stanton, Russ Tamblyn, Lee Van Cleef and Stanley Livingston. Stan plays George Peppard and Carolyn Jone's oldest son, Prescott Rawlings, in this Academy Award Winning Star Studded Western.

The Roman Holidays is a half-hour Saturday morning animated series produced by Hanna-Barbera Productions and broadcast on NBC from September 9 to December 2, 1972. Dom DeLuise as Mr. Evictus, Daws Butler as Brutus the Lion, Pamelyn Ferdin as Precocia Holiday, Stanley Livingston as Happius Holiday, Shirley Mitchell as Laurie Holiday, Harold Peary as Herman, Hal Smith as Mr. Tycoonius, Judy Strangis as Groovia.. Stan provided the Voice for Happius in this Hanna Barbera Animated TV Series.

Private Parts is an American horror film directed by Paul Bartel in his feature film debut, and starring Ayn Ruymen, Lucille Benson, John Ventantonio and Stanley Livingston. Its plot follows a troubled young woman who suspects a deviant serial killer is living among her in her aunt's dilapidated hotel in downtown Los Angeles. Young Cheryl moves into her estranged aunt Martha's rundown King Edward Hotel. One of its offbeat residents, disturbed photographer George, takes special interest in her. Cheryl begins suspecting that a resident was murdered. Overlooked when it was released by MGM in the mid 1970s, Private Parts became a Cult Film Favorite in the 1980s. These days this scary and bizarre Cult Film plays regularly - usually after midnight - on the TURNERN CHANNEL NETWORK. The Film was produced by Roger Cornamn's brother, Gene Corman.

Directed by Anthony Cardoza. Itâs Heavy Truckinâ, Hard Drivinâ, and Free Lovinâ! Some CB Outlaws attempt to rob an armored car. A crazy fun exploitation film that took advantage of the CB Radio craze that had swept America at the time. The Feature Film - staring James Keach and Stanley Livingston, played continuously on the Drive-in Movie Circuit back in the 1980s.

"In The Picture" is the first film photographed in 3-strip 35mm Wide Screen Cinerama Process in 50 years! "In The Picture" kicked off the Cinerama Film Festival at the Arclight Cinerama Dome. "In the Picture" was Directed by David Strohmaier. With Stanley Livingston, Paula Drake, Elizabeth Dominguez, Matthew Brewbaker. Produced by Dave Strohmaier, Anthony Saenz and Stanley Livingston. Stanley Livingston was also one of the stars of the last Cinerama Film made 50 years ago... the iconic western, "How The West Was Won".

The Last Days of Cinerama (Documentary) - The Last Days of Cinerama: Directed by Mike Celestino and produced by Robert Garren. With Dave Strohmaier, Stanley Livingston, Paula Drake, Matthew Brewbaker, Elizabeth Dominguez, John Sittig. A Documantary that covered the making of "IN THE PICTURE", the first 3-Strip 35mm Wide Screen Process CINERAMAÂ® film made in 50 years.

Attack of the 60 Foot Centerfolds is a satirical science fiction film directed by Fred Olen Ray starring J.J. North, Ted Monte, Tammy Parks, Raelyn Saalman, Nikki Fritz, John LaZar, Tim Abell, Stanley Livingston, Russ Tamblyn, Tommy Kirk. The film is a parody of Attack of the 50 Foot Woman (1958). Stan plays a Photo-Journalist who thinks he is on to a "BIG" story in this fun exploitation film produced by Roger Corman.

In the mid 1960's, the last of the old American television shows converted from black and white to color. At the same time, America was undergoing an epic cultural revolution. The Stars from those shows who were children, when we were children, witnessed those changes and the beginning of a new era of television.

An Award Winning highly recommended Five Part - Five Hour Long Series on the Business Side of Launching, Developing and Sustaining an Acting Career in the Entertainment Industry as it relates to Children, Teens and the Parents who supervise their careers. Produced and Directed by Stanley Livingston. The Instructors include 100 Entertainment Industry legends and veterans from both sides of the camera - 45 of whom have been nominated for, or won, EMMYÂ®, GOLDEN GLOBEÂ® and ACADEMY AWARDSÂ®. The President of the Screen Actors Guild and the President of the Directors Guild of America are also two of the Instructors.

Dad's here... Your Move! A father makes a surprise visit to Los Angeles to drop in on his four 40 something "Baby Boomer" aged sons. It is immediately apparent that Dad is less-than-welcome as he is quickly bounced from household to household. His four alienated and highly dysfunctional sons play a game of human "hot potato" with Dad as they humorously shirk the responsibility of spending time with dad, dealing with his eccentricities - and re-visiting the many skeletons in this family's closet. A dark family secret lies at the bottom of all this turmoil. Produced by Stanley Livingston and First Team Productions.
